text: Abd al-Hamid ibn Yahya al-Katib () was the secretary to the last Umayyad Caliph, Marwan II, and a supreme stylist of early Arabic prose.Islamic History in Arabia and Middle East Quote: :Cultivate the Arabic language so that you may speak correctly; develop a handsome script which will add luster to your writings; learn the poetry of the Arabs by heart; familiarize yourself with unusual ideas and expressions; read the history of the Arabs and the Persians, and remember their great deeds He may have been a descendant of a Persian captive at the battle of Qadesiya who became a mawlā (freedman) of the Qorashī clan of the Banu Amer b. Loʾayy. Some accounts, however, make the less likely claim that he was of this clan, hence of pure Arab descent. According to the Encyclopedia of Islam (3rd edition), Abd al-Hamid al-Katib was "a third- generation Muslim of non-Arab, probably Persian, extraction". ==References== Category:Year of birth missing Category:749 deaths Category:Medieval Arabic- language writers Category:People of the Umayyad Caliphate Category:Islamic mirrors for princes Category:Government of the Umayyad Caliphate Category:People of Iranian descent
